**Merry Clayton** (born December 25, 1948) is an American
[soul](/wiki/Soul_music "Soul music") and [gospel](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel
music") singer and an [actress](/wiki/Actress "Actress"). She provided a
number of backing [vocal](/wiki/Vocal_music "Vocal music") tracks for major
performing artists in the 1960s, most notably in her
[duet](/wiki/Duet_\(music\) "Duet \(music\)") with [Mick
Jagger](/wiki/Mick_Jagger "Mick Jagger") on the [Rolling
Stones](/wiki/Rolling_Stones "Rolling Stones") song "[Gimme
Shelter](/wiki/Gimme_Shelter "Gimme Shelter")."[1] Clayton is featured in _[20
Feet from Stardom](/wiki/20_Feet_from_Stardom "20 Feet from Stardom")_ , the
Oscar-winning documentary about background singers and their contributions to
the music industry. In 2013, she released _The Best of Merry Clayton_ , a
compilation of her favorite songs.

## Early
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Merry_Clayton&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life")]

Clayton was born in [Gert Town, New Orleans](/wiki/Gert_Town,_New_Orleans
"Gert Town, New Orleans"), [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"). Clayton
was born on Christmas Day, and earned her name due to the holiday. She is the
daughter of Eva B. Clayton and Reverend A.G. Williams Sr. Clayton was raised
in New Orleans as a Christian, and spent much of her time in her father’s
parish, New Zion Baptist Church. After moving to Los Angeles, she joined the
now famous singer group “[The Blossoms](/wiki/The_Blossoms "The Blossoms").”
[2]

##
Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Merry_Clayton&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Career")]

Clayton began her [recording](/wiki/Sound_recording_and_reproduction "Sound
recording and reproduction") career in 1962 at the age of 14, singing "Who Can
I Count On? (When I Can't Count on You)" as a duet with [Bobby
Darin](/wiki/Bobby_Darin "Bobby Darin") on his album "You're the Reason I'm
Living." In 1963 she recorded the first version of "[The Shoop Shoop Song
(It's in His Kiss)](/wiki/The_Shoop_Shoop_Song_\(It%27s_in_His_Kiss\) "The
Shoop Shoop Song \(It's in His Kiss\)")," the same year that [Betty
Everett](/wiki/Betty_Everett "Betty Everett")'s version reached the Top 10 on
the _[Billboard Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")_.[3]
Early in her career Merry performed with [Ray Charles](/wiki/Ray_Charles "Ray
Charles") (as one of [the Raelettes](/wiki/The_Raelettes "The Raelettes")),
who was the only artist her father allowed her to see live.[4] Others include
[Pearl Bailey](/wiki/Pearl_Bailey "Pearl Bailey"), [Phil Ochs](/wiki/Phil_Ochs
"Phil Ochs"), [Burt Bacharach](/wiki/Burt_Bacharach "Burt Bacharach"), [Tom
Jones](/wiki/Tom_Jones_\(singer\) "Tom Jones \(singer\)"), [Joe
Cocker](/wiki/Joe_Cocker "Joe Cocker"), [Linda Ronstadt](/wiki/Linda_Ronstadt
"Linda Ronstadt"), [Carole King](/wiki/Carole_King "Carole King"), and on
several tracks from [Neil Young](/wiki/Neil_Young "Neil Young")'s [debut
album](/wiki/Neil_Young_\(album\) "Neil Young \(album\)"). Clayton is often
credited as having recorded with [Elvis Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis
Presley") but her name does not appear in Elvis sessionographies.[5]

Clayton is best known for her 1969 duet with [Mick Jagger](/wiki/Mick_Jagger
"Mick Jagger") on the Rolling Stones song "[Gimme Shelter](/wiki/Gimme_Shelter
"Gimme Shelter")," though on some releases her name is misspelled as "Mary."
According to Jagger, this collaboration came about due partially to chance.
Jagger states that they thought “it’d be great to have a woman come do
the…chorus.” They called Clayton “randomly” in the middle of the night, and
she showed up to the studio “in curlers” and did the verse in a few takes,
which Jagger remarks is “pretty amazing.”[6] The Stones had asked [Bonnie
Bramlett](/wiki/Bonnie_Bramlett "Bonnie Bramlett") to sing on the song, but
Bramlett's husband, Delaney, refused to let her perform with the Stones.[7]
Clayton also sang backing vocals on [Lynyrd Skynyrd](/wiki/Lynyrd_Skynyrd
"Lynyrd Skynyrd")'s "[Sweet Home Alabama](/wiki/Sweet_Home_Alabama_\(song\)
"Sweet Home Alabama \(song\)")".[8]

In 1970, Clayton recorded her own version of "Gimme Shelter," and it became
the title track of her debut solo album and peaked at #73,[9] released that
year. Her version would be the first of five singles under her name to crack
the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"). That
same year she performed a live version of "[Lift Every Voice and
Sing](/wiki/Lift_Every_Voice_and_Sing "Lift Every Voice and Sing")" for the
soundtrack for [Robert Altman](/wiki/Robert_Altman "Robert Altman") film
_[Brewster McCloud](/wiki/Brewster_McCloud "Brewster McCloud")_ and also
contributed vocals to [Donald Cammell](/wiki/Donald_Cammell "Donald Cammell")
and [Nicolas Roeg](/wiki/Nicolas_Roeg "Nicolas Roeg")'s film
_[Performance](/wiki/Performance_\(film\) "Performance \(film\)")_. In 1971
she co-wrote the song "Sho' Nuff" about her mother.[10] She starred as the
original [Acid Queen](/wiki/Acid_Queen "Acid Queen") in the first
[London](/wiki/London "London") production of [The Who](/wiki/The_Who "The
Who")'s _[Tommy](/wiki/Tommy_\(rock_opera\)#1972_orchestral_version "Tommy
\(rock opera\)")_ in 1972. In 1973, she featured prominently on Ringo Starr's
"Oh My My", which reached Billboard's Top 10 the following year.

In the mid 1970s, Clayton sang on [The Blackbyrds](/wiki/The_Blackbyrds "The
Blackbyrds")' R&B hit "Rock Creek Park" and continued to release solo albums
throughout the next decade, notching several minor [R&B](/wiki/R%26B "R&B")
singles. Her soundtrack work continued into the 1980s, including "You're
Always There When I Need You", the title track for the 1980 _[Get
Smart](/wiki/Get_Smart "Get Smart")_ film _[The Nude Bomb](/wiki/The_Nude_Bomb
"The Nude Bomb")_ , and the song "Yes" from _[Dirty
Dancing](/wiki/Dirty_Dancing "Dirty Dancing")_ , which hit #45 on the Hot 100.
In 1987, Clayton co-starred with [Ally Sheedy](/wiki/Ally_Sheedy "Ally
Sheedy") in the film _[Maid to Order](/wiki/Maid_to_Order "Maid to Order")_
and played Verna Dee Jordan in the final season of _[Cagney&
Lacey](/wiki/Cagney_%26_Lacey "Cagney & Lacey")_. In 1989, she recorded a
cover of "[Almost Paradise](/wiki/Almost_Paradise "Almost Paradise")" with
[Eric Carmen](/wiki/Eric_Carmen "Eric Carmen").[11]

In 1994 Clayton recorded backing vocals for and sang the "Man with the Golden
Gun" bridge on [Tori Amos](/wiki/Tori_Amos "Tori Amos")'s hit, "[Cornflake
Girl](/wiki/Cornflake_Girl "Cornflake Girl")".

In 2006, Clayton provided background vocals for [Sparta](/wiki/Sparta_\(band\)
"Sparta \(band\)")'s album _[Threes](/wiki/Threes_\(album\) "Threes
\(album\)")_ on the songs "Atlas" and "Translations".

She was featured in the documentary film _[20 Feet from
Stardom](/wiki/20_Feet_from_Stardom "20 Feet from Stardom")_ (2013), which
premiered at the [Sundance Film Festival](/wiki/2013_Sundance_Film_Festival
"2013 Sundance Film Festival") and went on to win the Oscar for best
documentary at the [86th Academy Awards](/wiki/86th_Academy_Awards "86th
Academy Awards"). _20 Feet from Stardom_ also won the 2015 [Grammy Award for
Best Music Film](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Music_Film "Grammy Award for Best
Music Film"), with the award being presented to the featured artists as well
as the production crew.

In 2014, Clayton provided vocals for [G. Love & Special
Sauce](/wiki/G._Love_%26_Special_Sauce "G. Love & Special Sauce")'s album
_Sugar_.

In 2015, Clayton was featured on two tracks on [Coldplay](/wiki/Coldplay
"Coldplay")'s album _[A Head Full of Dreams](/wiki/A_Head_Full_of_Dreams "A
Head Full of Dreams")_.

Clayton has been sampled in various songs, most notably _Watch for the Hook_
by Cool Breeze featuring [Goodie Mobb](/wiki/Goodie_Mob "Goodie Mob") and
supergroup [Outkast](/wiki/Outkast "Outkast").[12]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Merry_Clayton&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Clayton was married to [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") artist [Curtis
Amy](/wiki/Curtis_Amy "Curtis Amy") from 1970 until his death in 2002.[13]
Clayton's brother is the [Little Feat](/wiki/Little_Feat "Little Feat")
[percussionist](/wiki/Percussionist "Percussionist") [Sam
Clayton](/wiki/Sam_Clayton "Sam Clayton").[14]

She had a miscarriage upon returning home from recording "Gimme Shelter",
according to the _LA Times._[15]

On June 16, 2014, Clayton was severely injured in a car accident in [Los
Angeles, California](/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California "Los Angeles,
California").[16] Both of Clayton's legs were later amputated at the knees due
to her suffering "profound trauma to her lower extremities" as a result of the
accident.[17]
